ygData.subject: Re: Species stagnation
ygData.msgSnippet: Ken, Many thanks for the response.  That does indeed clear up a whole lot. ... That makes perfect sense, thank you. ... I see now how powerful this could be

Ken,

Many thanks for the response.  That does indeed clear up a whole lot.

>> [inquiry regarding "lowest performing species older than N
>> generations is sterilized"]

> I know what happened here.  The papers you are talking about are 
> coevolution experiments.  In coevolution, you can't use absolute 
> fitness to check for stagnation since fitness is *relative* in 
> coevolution.  In other words, even if the fitness of a species 
> stayed the same for 100 generations, that doesn't mean that its 
> performance is staying the same in coevolution.  It might be worse 
> and it might be better, in an absolute sense, than where it started.
> Therefore, it uses the heuristic you mentioned, where it just culls 
> the worst species as long as it's been around for a while.

That makes perfect sense, thank you.

> The point of this special "delta coding" case is that the entire 
> population is stuck, and you have nothing available to work with 
> other than the current population.  It makes sense in that case to 
> *focus in* on the best species, simply because they are most 
> promising by virtue of being most fit.  Since basically everyone is 
> stagnating, there isn't anything else to go on.  

I see now how powerful this could be (didn't see the connection to
SANE until now).  However, isn't there a major risk that if the best
species is stuck in or near a local minima that the entire population
will simply get stuck in there as well?  In my experiment, when it
goes nowhere, I find that the "delta coding" simply ensures that every
genome is the same and then they all go nowhere together.

> Finally, let me suggest that from reading about your (Mike's)
> specific problem that it is probably something about the domain that 
> is causing you to get stuck.  It may simply be too hard to evolve 
> from scratch, or there could be a bug.  But I have a feeling that 
> stagnation detection is not the primary factor in this problem.

I think that you are right and I am now looking at the problem with,
what feels like, fresh eyes.  Thanks!

Mike
